Legal_Issue: Whether the RPD's decision to reject Mr. Huang's refugee claim based on lack of Christian knowledge was unreasonable
Governing_Law: Standard set by the Supreme Court in [2008] S.C.J. 9
Evidence_Assessment: Mr. Huang demonstrated reasonable knowledge of Christianity despite minor errors; RPD focused excessively on these errors
Decision_Outcome: RPD rejected Mr. Huang's refugee claim due to insufficient Christian knowledge
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to establish well-founded fear of persecution
Credibility_Factor: Knowledge of Christian beliefs assessed as part of credibility
Legal_Rule: RPD decision must not be unreasonable under the standard of reasonableness
Procedural_Issue: Alleged unfair application of an unrealistically high standard by the RPD
Grounds_for_Claim: Persecution for membership in an underground Christian church
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: RPD applied an overly strict and unfair standard in assessing religious knowledge
Key_Evidence_Considered: Mr. Huang's testimony about his Christian faith and practices, including knowledge of religious teachings
Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, Canadian administrative law principles
Applicant_Challenge: Challenged RPD's assessment of his credibility based on religious knowledge
Court_Result: RPD decision overturned; case remitted to a different panel for reassessment
Remedy_Requested: Vacatur of RPD decision and reassessment of refugee claim
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review allowing for re-determination of refugee claim
Resolution_Mechanism: Judicial review followed by re-hearing before a new RPD panel
Legal_Provision: Section 96 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Lack of credibility regarding religious belief
